Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Middle Pleistocene Hominin Behavior and Paleoecology at Farre, Chalbi Basin, Northern Kenya

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
The African early Middle Pleistocene saw the emergence of archaic Homo, the expansion of hominin brain capacities to near-modern dimensions, and the first appearance of a battery of sophisticated new technologies. And yet, as relatively few African localities sample this important timeframe (i.e. the period from c.781-500ka), the specific details regarding the timing, setting, and dynamics that underlie the emergence and early evolution of these advances remain poorly understood. With an estimated minimum age of c.600-500ka, recent paleoanthropological discoveries at the open-air site of Farre, located in the Chalbi Basin of northern Kenya, may add important new data relevant to these issues. In this project, an interdisciplinary team of investigators will conduct a two-year archaeological and geochronological study to better understand the age and contents of the Farre site. Broader impacts of the project include the opportunity to build research collaborations across universities, museums, and research centers, research and training opportunities for students and junior faculty, and public education and conservation outreach at the field site and in the U.S.

During two seasons of paleoanthropological fieldwork at Farre, the investigators will expand preliminary excavations to further document the presence of in situ archaeological materials, increase the sample size of diagnostic artifact forms and fossil taxa, refine the geoarchaeology and paleoenvironmental setting of the site; and refine the geochronology of site. Finds from preliminary excavations include artifacts consistent with both Early and Middle Stone Age technologies, coupled with fossil taxa suggesting an age in excess of 500ka. Farre may thus help bridge a long-standing gap in the record of this paleoanthropologically-important region, refine our understanding of the emergence and early evolution of important technological capacities, and place inferred hominin adaptations within local, regional, and global paleoenvironmental contexts.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The African Middle Pleistocene saw the emergence of Homo sapiens and the appearance of a battery of sophisticated new technologies. And yet, as relatively few African localities sample this important timeframe (i.e. the period from c.781–126ka), the specific details regarding the timing, setting, and dynamics that underlie the emergence and evolution of these advances remain poorly understood. With a presumed Middle Pleistocene age, recent paleoanthropological discoveries at the open-air site of Farre, located in the Chalbi Basin of northern Kenya, add important new data relevant to these issues
With National Science Foundation support, an international interdisciplinary team conducted a multi-year investigation of the Farre locality and its contents. Fossils and artifacts, numbering in the thousands, were found blanketed across the top of a low hill. These included Levallois points, a handaxe, and numerous teeth of Eurygnathohippus (last appearance datum: c.500ka). A subsequent excavation (GfJo2) yielded >4000 artifacts and fossils in situ. Finds included artifacts consistent with Middle Stone Age technologies, coupled with numerous postcranial fossils of bovids and equids. Our team is currently working to refine the stratigraphy and geochronology of the site, which will allow researchers to accurately place inferred hominin adaptations within local, regional, and global paleoenvironmental contexts. Ongoing archaeological analyses are aimed at refining our understanding of the evolution of important technological capacities (including the production of stone points and Levallois flake-based reduction techniques) as well as to help elucidate the content and context of hominin dietary and foraging adaptations. Collectively, these studies will improve our understanding of Middle Pleistocene hominin paleobiology in sub-Saharan Africa, a topic of considerable interest and importance, but for which we currently possess relatively little data.
It is notable that discoveries at Farre are unique in the region and may help bridge the ‘Middle Pleistocene gap’ in the geological record of the nearby paleoanthropologically-important Turkana Basin, as well as add increased time-depth to regional time-series analyses of biotic responses to climate change. In a similar vein, discoveries at Farre meet a recent request from the National Research Council to discover and investigate new hominin localities in Africa with which we can address issues of hominin-environment interactions and the emergence of key anatomical, technological and sociocultural adaptations.
In addition to discoveries at Farre, systematic surveys of the region yielded a pair of hominin fossils at a nearby site, as well as numerous tuff samples recovered from across the southern and southeastern margins of the basin. ‘Fingerprinting’ these latter discoveries will help elucidate the basin’s geological history, as well as to help integrate findings from the Chalbi with those from other basins (e.g., Turkana). Preliminary results suggest that the sampled tuffs range in age from the Pliocene to Late Pleistocene.
Broader impacts of the project included building substantial ‘research bridges’ between collaborators at universities, museums, and research centers from across the United States, Africa, Europe and Australia. It also created research opportunities for graduate students, post-docs, and faculty alike, as well as training opportunities for undergraduate students in US lab-based contexts, and field and lab-based opportunities for undergraduate and graduate students and select staff from the National Museums of Kenya. Moreover, the project engaged the local Rendille community (and women in particular; an underrepresented demographic in East African paleoanthropological field crews) in excavation and education/site-conservation efforts. Disseminating the results of our study is an important goal for our project: in addition to planned submissions of journal manuscripts and meeting abstracts, we have begun to disseminate our research findings in a range of forums, including Museum lectures in the US and informal lectures to Rendille community members.
